title: Stability and Approximation in Group Theory
description: This lecture course deals with the following type of questions. Given a family of groups G_n with bi-invariant metrics d_n and H a finitely generated group, a group is (G_n,d_n)-approximated if it has a family of “separating almost homomorphisms” into G_n. Example 1: G_n+Sym(n) with the normalized Hamming metric gives the sofic groups. Example 2: G_n=U(n) with the Hilbert-Schmidt norm gives the hyperlinear groups. Famous problems of Gromov (resp., Connes) asks whether every group is sofic (resp., hyperlinear). While these are still open, a recent breakthrough gave a solution for the same problem with G-N=U(n) and d_n=the L^2 norm. The key ingredient is the theory of stability, which asks: Is every almost homomorphism “close” to an actual homomorphis? Some progress on this theory was made recently using the new theory of IRS. The proof also uses the seminal work of Garland on lattices in simple Lie groups. No prior knowledge is assumed.
regnotes:
